journal-meta.journal-title: The Journal of Strain Analysis for Engineering Design

title-group.article-title: Interpretation of small ring creep test data

contrib-group.aff: Department of Mechanical, Materials and Manufacturing Engineering, University of Nottingham, UK

author-notes.corresp: Wei Sun, Department of Mechanical, Materials and Manufacturing Engineering, University of Nottingham, University Park, Nottingham NG7 2RD, UK. Email: w.sun@nottingham.ac.uk

abstract.p: The small ring creep test method can be used to generate uniaxial secondary creep strain rate data from small samples of material. The technique used is based on the reference stress method; it enables the load-line displacement rates, obtained from testing the rings, to be converted to equivalent uniaxial creep strain rates. Accurate conversion relationships are required, in order to ensure that accurate creep properties are obtained. In this article, an analysis of the creep behaviour of small, ring-type specimens and the associated test procedures are described. This includes the determination of the conversion factors, which are used to convert the minimum creep displacement rate to the equivalent uniaxial minimum creep strain rate and to convert the nominal stress to the equivalent uniaxial stress, using the finite element method. In addition, an assessment of the effects of ring dimensions, for example, the radial thickness and mean radius, on the conversion factors, is made. Finally, the effects of the small geometry changes that occur during a test, on the conversion factors, are investigated.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Components in chemical plant, power generation plant, aeroengines and so on, operate at temperatures and stresses that are high enough to cause creep to occur.1 In the quest for improved efficiencies, lower emissions and fuel diversification, new materials are being introduced, and these are being subjected to increasingly severe loading conditions (see Saber et al.,2 Tanner et al.3 and Peravali et al.4). In order to ensure the safe operation of components, improved understanding of the creep behaviour of the materials being used to manufacture them and improved inspection techniques are required.1,5,6 One effect of the desire to improve understanding of material behaviours and to obtain better inspection techniques, is the need, in some cases, to use small material samples (see Parker et al.,7 Sun et al.8 and Sturm et al.9). This comes about because small scoop samples can be removed from some components, for example, steam pipes and pipe bends, without adversely affecting their safe operation. Also, for some material zones, for example, the heat-affected zones (HAZ) of welds, only small amounts of material are available for testing.

A conventional uniaxial creep test specimen has the dimensions indicated in Figure 1. However, the dimensions of a typical scoop sample (see Figure 2) are far too small to allow a conventional uniaxial test specimen to be extracted from it. Therefore, it has become necessary to develop small specimen test techniques. These include conventional, sub-size creep test specimens (Figure 3(a)), impression creep test specimens (Figure 3(b)), small punch creep test specimens (Figure 3(c)) and small ring creep test specimens (Figure 3(d)). This article is concerned with the use of small elliptical ring creep test specimens. In particular, the effects of the bo/d and a/d ratios (Figure 4) on the conversion factors η and β, which relate5,10 (1) the specimen load and dimensions to the corresponding uniaxial stress and (2) the specimen’s load-line displacement and dimensions to the corresponding uniaxial strain, have been investigated. The investigation also includes the effects of the ellipse ratio, a/b, and the effects of the geometry change that occurs during a test, as it progresses.

caption.p: Conventional uniaxial creep test specimen.2
(a) Photograph of a scoop sample and (b) dimensions of a typical scoop sample

Small specimen creep test specimens: (a) conventional sub-size creep test specimen (GL ≈ 5–12 mm; dGL≈ 1–3 mm); (b) impression creep test specimen (w = bi≈ 10 mm, di≈ 1 mm, h ≈ 2.5 mm, loading area is bidi); (c) small punch creep test specimen (Di≈ 8 mm, to≈ 0.5 mm); and (d) circular ring creep test specimen(D ≈ 5–20 mm; d ≈ 1–2 mm).5
Analytical model of the elliptical ring specimen: (a and b) loading and geometry definition and (c) free body diagram.5

sec.p: If it is assumed that the ring can be accurately represented by curved beam theory, then the minimum complementary strain energy theorem can be readily used to obtain an expression to relate the load-line displacement (or displacement rate) to the load and the ring dimensions. The solution has been described in detail,5,10 and therefore, only a brief description is given in the ‘PS, thin ring analytical solution based on beam theory’ section of this article. In effect, the analytical solution neglects the contributions that shear deformations make to the deformation of the ring. The beam theory also neglects the effect of the axial length, bo, of the ring; for small axial lengths, that is, bo/d is small, the ring deforms under approximately plane stress (PS) conditions, whereas for larger axial lengths, bo/d, the ring deforms under approximately plane strain (PE) conditions. For the already published work,5,10 a/b is either 1 (circular) or 2 (elliptical) with a/d = 5 and bo/d = 1; comparisons of the predictions with experimental results indicate that the PS thin ring theory is highly accurate for the chosen dimensions.

In some circumstances, it may be convenient to use rings with a/b and bo/d, which are not so closely related to the thin ring geometries. Also, the testing of specimens with higher and lower ellipse ratios (a/b) may be required. For these conditions, the finite element (FE) method is used to obtain the variations of the conversion factors, η and β, with bo/d and a/d, for a range of a/b ratios. This investigation is discussed in the ‘FE analysis’ section. The analytical (in the ‘PS, thin ring analytical solution based on beam theory’ section) and FE (in the ‘FE analysis’ section) solutions are used as the basis of the inverse reference stress method used to obtain the η and β values. The applicabilities of the η and β values obtained from the thin ring PS, PE and three-dimensional (3D) analyses are assessed in the ‘Results of theoretical and FE investigations’ section.

The ‘Comparison of uniaxial creep data with predictions based on small ring creep tests’ section describes a comparison between experimental results based on the small ring creep test data, converted to corresponding uniaxial data, with the corresponding uniaxial creep test data. The practical implications of this work are summarised and conclusions are given in ‘Discussion and conclusion’ section.

where R is the mean ring radius. The theoretically obtained variations of η and β with the ratio of the major to minor axis, that is, a/b, are presented in Figure 5. It can be seen that the value of η is practically independent of the a/b ratio, while the value of β varies approximately linearly with the a/b ratio.

caption.p: The variations of the η and β parameters with the a/b ratio.5

sec.title: Scope of investigation
sec.p: The analytical solution presented in the ‘PS, thin ring analytical solution based on beam theory’ section does not include the contribution that shear deformation makes to the overall deformation, and hence, it does not include the effect that shear deformation has on the conversion factors, η and β. In order to assess the effect, a series of elastic-creep FE analyses using Norton’s creep law have been performed using a range of a/d, bo/d and a/b values. Under steady-state conditions, the stresses and the deformation rates are independent of time. From the results of the FE analyses, the variations of the conversion factors with the geometric parameters (a/d, bo/d and a/b) have been obtained. A limited study was also carried out to assess the effects of the small geometry changes on the ring deformation behaviour. The ABAQUS FE software package12 was used for the FE investigations.

sec.title: Geometries, meshes and boundary conditions
sec.p: The two extremes of behaviour, that is, PS and PE, were investigated using meshes consisting of eight-noded PS and PE isoparametric elements, respectively. The intermediate behaviour was investigated using meshes that consist of 20-noded brick elements. Because of the symmetry, it was only necessary to model one-quarter of the ring and one-half of the ring thickness for the 3D case; typical FE meshes are shown in Figure 6. The boundary conditions, ux = 0 on plane A, uy = 0 on plane B and uz = 0 on plane C, are also indicated in Figure 6.

caption.p: Typical finite element meshes used for (a) PS and PE cases and (b) 3D cases.

sec.title: Elliptical ring geometries
sec.p: Two methods have been used to create the elliptical ring geometry. The simplest method is to create two concentric ellipses (see Figure 7(a)); this results in a variable thickness, d, in the elliptical ring. The thicknesses are the same (i.e. the required d value) at the positions of the major and minor axes. An alternative method, which produces a uniform thickness, d, is the ‘offset ellipses’ method that is created using an ellipse as the mid-thickness geometry. The inside and the outside surfaces are then traced out by the position of the centre of a pin of diameter, d, which is imagined to be rolled around the mid-thickness ellipses, as illustrated in Figure 7(b) and (c).

caption.p: Elliptical ring geometries: (a) concentric ellipses, (b) offset ellipses and (c) the method used to define the offset ellipse geometry.

sec.title: Geometries and material behaviour model used for the analyses
sec.p: In all calculations, the a value was kept constant with a nominal value of 10 mm; note, when the results are normalised (see the ‘Results of theoretical and FE investigations’ section) the a value chosen is unimportant. The analyses were performed with a/b = 0.5, 0.66, 1, 1.5 and 2, for d values of 0.5, 1.0, 1.5 and 2.0 mm. A Norton material behaviour model, that is

was used in all of the calculations performed. As with the dimensions used in the analyses, the actual value of B used is not important because the results have been normalised (see the ‘Results of theoretical and FE investigations’ section). FE results were obtained for n values, in the range of 1–10. It is necessary to use a range of n values, in order to determine the specific value of α, which makes the

caption.p: Determination of β and η values, for a ring specimen with d = 1, a/b = 1 and a/d = 10.

sec.title: Results of theoretical and FE investigations
Differences between the η and β values obtained with ‘concentric ellipses’ and ‘offset ellipses’ geometries
sec.p: Depending on whether the ellipse geometry is created using ‘concentric’ or ‘offset’ ellipses, the relative thicknesses will be different at different angular positions, θ (see Figure 4). Hence the η and β values will be different. The variations of the η and β values with d/a, under PS conditions, for the two ellipse geometry types, with a range of ellipticity ratios, a/b, are shown in Figure 9. The β values obtained for the concentric ellipses (see Figure 7(a)) are found to be slightly higher than the values obtained from the offset ellipses (see Figure 7(b)) for all a/b ratios examined, except for the circular ring, where a/b = 1. These differences can be related to the fact that the concentric ellipses have non-uniform thicknesses, especially when a/b ≤ 0.66 and a/b ≥ 1.5. As a consequence of the slightly lower cross-sectional area, that is, d × bo, the displacement rates are greater, when compared with those obtained with offset ellipses, for the same a/b and d/a values. Therefore, the β values for the ‘concentric ellipses’ are greater than the corresponding values for the ‘offset ellipses’, as can be seen in Figure 9. However, the η values are practically independent of the modelling procedure and result in η value of about 0.9 for all the a/b and d/a ratios used in this study, for both the geometric modelling types.

caption.p: Comparison of the β values obtained for offset ellipses with those obtained for concentric ellipses.
PS: plane stress.

sec.title: Transverse deformations
sec.p:
Deformations occur during a ring specimen test, in particular the measured load-line displacement (
Δ
·
V
) is accompanied by the transverse displacement (
Δ
·
H
). As a result, slight changes in the aspect ratio, a/b, occur because the a value decreases and the b value increases, for the case of ‘tensile loading’, as indicated in Figure 4(b). From this perspective, it is desirable to use a ring geometry (i.e. a/b) for which the small changes in a/b that occur during a test have an insignificant effect on η and β values. Analytical expressions for the displacement rates in the vertical (increasing b) and horizontal (decreasing a) directions have been obtained for ring specimens under PS creep condition using equations (11) and (12), that is

are obtained from the FE analyses and the analytical results and are plotted against the a/b ratio in Figure 10. It can be seen that there is good agreement between the analytical and the FE results, especially when the specimens are very thin, for example, a/d ≥ 10, which is where it would be expected that the effects of contribution of shear deformations to the overall deformation would be negligible.

sec.p:
Based on the results of the analytical and FE analyses for a circular ring, the ratios of the
Δ
·
H
/
Δ

were found to be approximately unity; the small increase in the b value and decrease in the a value, which occurs as a result of the creep deformation, were found to be almost the same. Therefore, the change in the ring geometry that occurs during a test for relatively small deformation may be neglected for the case of circular rings.

sec.title: Effects of relative dimensions on the η and β values for circular specimens
Effect of the bo/d ratio on the η and β values
sec.p: The FE analyses were carried out using PS, PE and 3D models, with offset ellipse geometries, to assess the effect of the bo/d ratio on the β and η values. Various values of bo were used, while all other ring dimensions were kept constant for the analyses. The 3D specimen model dimensions are shown in Figure 4, where the values for bo, in the 3D analyses, were taken to be 0.25–40 mm. The results (Figure 11(a) and (b)) show that under PS conditions, where bo is very small, that is, close to 0, β and η have the highest values, which are 0.482 and 0.91, respectively. Under PE conditions, where bo is large, that is, the bo/d ratio is effectively infinite, β and η have the lowest values, which are 0.415 and 0.79, respectively. The β and η values obtained from the 3D analyses varied between those obtained from the PS and the PE conditions, that is, as bo decreases, the values of β and η become very close to those obtained for the PS conditions, while as the bo increases the β and η values become practically constant, being nearly equal to the values obtained for the PE conditions.

caption.p: The values of (a) β and (b) η for PS, PE and 3D analyses, for circular specimens with d = 2 mm and various bo/d ratios.
PS: plane stress; PE: plane strain; 3D: three-dimensional.

sec.title: Effect of d/a on the conversion factors η and β
sec.p: PS analyses were carried out in order to study the effects of the d/a ratio, for offset ellipse geometries, on the β and η values, with various a/b ratios. The analyses show that for all the a/b ratios used, the β values increase slightly as the d/a ratio increases, as shown in Figure 12. Moreover, it can be seen that, for all a/b ratios, the β values vary approximately linearly with d/a. This indicates that when the ring thickness, d, is close to 0 (represented by the theoretical solution in the ‘PS, thin ring analytical solution based on beam theory’ section), the effects of shear deformation are negligible, and the β value is low for all a/b ratios used; β gradually increases as the d/a ratios increase. In contrast, the η values were found to be practically constant, being around 0.9 for all ring geometries analysed.

caption.p: The effects of d/a on β and η values, for various a/b ratios.
PS: plane stress.

sec.p: The results show that the effects of shear deformation on the β and η values, for all d/a ratios in the range of d/a = 0.05–0.20 and for all a/b ratios in the range of a/b = 0.5 to a/b = 2.0, is very small. Therefore, for practical purposes, the effects of shear deformation can be neglected, as can be seen in Figure 12.

sec.title: Comparison of uniaxial creep data with predictions based on small ring creep tests
sec.p: Uniaxial specimens (Figure 1) and circular ring specimens (a/b = 1, a/d = R/d = 5, where R = D/2) were manufactured from a P91 steel and creep tested at 650 °C. The uniaxial creep curves obtained for stresses of 70, 82, 87, 93 and 100 Mpa are shown in Figure 13, from which it can be seen that the creep behaviour is typical of that for many materials; it exhibits primary, secondary and tertiary regions.5 The minimum creep strain rate (MSR) plotted against the stress (using log–log scales) is shown in Figure 14. The B and n values in Norton’s law can be obtained by straight line fitting to the log(MSR)–log(σ) plots (Figure 14). The results obtained from uniaxial date are: n = 8.234 and B = 2.472 × 10−20, and the results obtained from the ring test are: n = 7.241 and B = 1.702 × 10−18. Table 1 compares the minimum strain rates calculated using those constants and Norton’s law.

caption.p: Creep strain versus time curves obtained from uniaxial tests for P91 steel at 650 °C.
MSR data for P91 steel at 650 °C.5
MSR: minimum creep strain rate.
Comparison of the MSRs calculated by using the B and n values in Norton’s law (equation (10)) obtained from ring creep test and uniaxial creep test data.

sec.p: The circular ring specimen geometries were such that η and β values of 0.9 and 0.45, respectively, apply, as seen in Figure 5. Four specimens were tested with loads corresponding to uniaxial stresses of 50, 55, 60 and 65 Mpa, respectively, using equation (8) to calculate the load. The load-point displacements versus time curves, obtained from the ring tests, are shown in Figure 15. Equation (9) was used to convert the minimum deformation rate data to MSR data. This is shown together with the uniaxial data in Figure 14. The correlation between the uniaxial and the small ring data is remarkably good.

caption.p: Variation of Δ/R with time obtained from creep tests for diametrically loaded P91 circular rings, at 650 °C.5

sec.title: Discussion and conclusions
sec.p: Small specimen creep testing is useful in a number of practical engineering situations (see Parker et al.,7 Sturm et al.9 and Garzillo et al.13). It can be used to obtain the current creep strength of a service-aged material using, for example, scoop samples removed from a component,5 or to obtain the creep properties of a HAZ region of a weld (see Peravali et al.,4 Garzillo et al.13 and Dorner et al.14), or to obtain the relative creep properties of materials produced as part of an alloy development programme and so on. For example, the MSR obtained from a service-aged material can be used with the Monkman–Grant relationship to estimate component life. The usefulness of a particular small specimen test method depends on the ease with which specimens can be manufactured and tested and the ease with which the measured deformations can be converted to corresponding uniaxial creep data.

Small ring specimens, particularly circular rings, can be manufactured and tested as easily as any other commonly used small specimen type (i.e. small punch, impression creep and sub-size uniaxial test specimens). Creep testing of circular, small ring specimens, is made easy by the self-centring property of the specimen. Also, the measured deformation is not related to localised creep strains that occur at the region of contact between the test specimen and the loading device (e.g. the impression creep test method); it depends on the bending that occurs at every circumferential position of the ring. Hence, it is not necessary to have a loading device with significantly higher creep strength than the tested material. The sensitivity of the measured deformations is very important if the predicted creep strains, corresponding to uniaxial data, are to be produced with reasonably high accuracy. A simple measure of the relative sensitivities of particularly small specimen test types is given by the equivalent gauge length (EGL). Typical ring test dimensions, that is, R = 5 and d = 1 mm, result in a β value of about 0.5, leading to an EGL of about the same magnitude as a conventional uniaxial creep test specimen (see Figure 1) with a gauge length of 50 mm.

The bo value chosen for a test may have a significant effect on both the η value and the β value. Small bo/d values (i.e. bo/d < 2) correspond to the PS conditions (see Figure 11(a) and (b)) and large bo/d values (i.e. bo/d>15) correspond to the PE conditions (see Figure 11(a) and (b)).

It should be noted that the expressions for the σref value (e.g. equation (6)) and the
ε
·
c
(
σ
ref
) value
(e.g. equation (7)) do not contain any material properties, that is, the conversion process (from small specimen data to corresponding uniaxial data) is material independent.

In some situations, the dimensions and shape of the small samples of material available may make it more beneficial to test elliptical, rather than circular, specimens. In this case, two types of geometries have been investigated, that is, ‘concentric ellipses’ and ‘offset ellipses’. Essentially, the difference is that the offset ellipse geometry produces a constant thickness, d, as is the situation assumed when deriving the analytical solution (the ‘PS, thin ring analytical solution based on beam theory’ section); the concentric ellipse geometry has a variable thickness. The offset ellipse approach is recommended based on the results presented in this article (see Figure 9). The variations of η and β with a/b (the ellipticity ratio) are shown in Figure 5.

In general, the small change in shape, which a specimen undergoes as a test progresses, has a relatively insignificant effect on the
σ
ref
and
ε
·
(
σ
ref
)
, which exist during a test. The results shown in Figure 14 indicate that the experimental small ring test data can be converted into the corresponding uniaxial data with remarkable accuracy.

It is concluded that the small ring test method is capable of producing data that correspond to uniaxial creep data. Also, it is recommended that the circular ring should be used where practical; R/d ≈ 5 allows easy interpretation of the test data.
